tn.text: This is the eighth month of the Hebrew calendar. It is during the last part of October and the first part of November on Western calendars. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_hebrewmonths]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
"second year since Darius became king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
"Yahweh spoke his word" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is the name of God that he revealed to his people in the Old Testament. See the translationWord page about Yahweh concerning how to translate this.
These are the names of males. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"very angry with your forefathers"
The word "turn" is used to refer to a change. Yahweh is telling the people of Israel to change from not obeying him to obeying him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: this is the declaration of Yahweh of hosts
tn.text: This phrase is often translated as "Yahweh says" in the UDB. You can translate this concept whichever way is best in your language. This phrase is used many times in Zechariah.

By saying he will return to the people of Israel, Yahweh is saying that they will have good things happen because he is helping them. AT: "I will bless you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"shouted"
"Change"

tn.ref: But they would not hear and did not pay attention to me
tn.text: Both of these phrases mean that the people of Israel would not obey the commands of Yahweh. AT: "But they would not listen to my commands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This phrase is often translated as "Yahweh says" in the UDB. You can translate this concept whichever way is best in your language. This phrase is used many times in Zechariah.

tn.ref: Your fathers, where are they? Where are the prophets, are they here forever?
tn.text: Both of these questions are asked to point out the fact that people die. AT: "Your fathers have died. The prophets will also die." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: But my words and my decrees that I commanded my servants the prophets, have they not overtaken your fathers?
tn.text: This question is used to show the people of Israel that everything that the Lord had told his prophets to warn their ancestors about, had happened. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
These are both ways to refer to what God has said to the prophets. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Yahweh speaks about his prophecies like they are running to catch up and pass the ancestors of the people of Israel. The word "overtaken" means passed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"our behavior and actions"

tn.ref: the twenty-fourth day of the eleventh month, which is the month of Shebat
tn.text: fourth day of the eleventh month, which is the month of Shebat** - "Shebat" is the eleventh month of the Hebrew calendar. The twenty-fourth day is near the middle of February on Western calendars. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_hebrewmonths]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"Yahweh spoke his word." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:zec:01:01|1:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
a kind of small tree with colorful flowers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
The words "these" and "they" refer to the horses among the myrtle trees.
Possible meanings: 1) "patrol the entire world" or 2) "walk throughout the earth"
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:zec:01:07|1:8]].

tn.ref: all the earth sits still and is at rest
tn.text: AT: "all the people in the world are at peace"

tn.ref: sits still and is at rest
tn.text: Both of these phrases refer to being able to relax without anything to worry about. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Possible meanings 1) "you have been angry with" (UBD) or 2) "have been treated with disrespect"

tn.ref: talked with me, with good words, words of comfort
tn.text: These phrases describe words that are both good and comforting. AT: "encouraged me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hendiadys]])

tn.ref: I am very angry with the nations that are at ease
tn.text: AT: "I am very angry with the nations that enjoy peace and security"

tn.ref: I was only a little angry
tn.text: AT: "I was only a little angry with the people of Judah" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: I have returned to Jerusalem with mercies
tn.text: Returning to Jerusalem refers to once again taking care of the people of Israel like a king returning to lead his people out of trouble. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: My house will be built within her
tn.text: AT: "My temple will be built in Jerusalem"

tn.ref: this is the declaration of Yahweh of hosts
tn.text: This phrase is often translated as "Yahweh says" in the UDB. You can translate this concept whichever way is best in your language. This phrase is used many times in Zechariah.

tn.ref: the measuring line will be stretched out over Jerusalem!
tn.text: AT: "Jerusalem will be surveyed before rebuilding"

tn.ref: My cities will once again overflow with goodness
tn.text: Yahweh refers to the good things he will do for the people of Israel like a liquid that could fill the cities and flow over the walls. AT: "The cities of Israel will once again be prosperous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
AT: "Yahweh will encourage the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Zechariah continues to describe his vision.
This phrase refers to turning your head to look up. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: the horns that have scattered Judah
tn.text: These horns represent the armies that attacked the people of Israel. AT: "Those horns represent the nations" (UDB).
Yahweh continues to describe Zechariah's vision for him.
People with this job make things out of metal. They are used to refer to the swords of an army. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
See note in [[:en:bible:notes:zec:01:18|1:18]].

tn.ref: no man would lift up his head
tn.text: This phrase describes someone who is too afraid to look something that scares him. AT: "no man would have courage" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"drive those nations out"
"to defeat the armies"
This refers to blowing a horn to command an army. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
